PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIA, JAPAN AND SOUTH KOREA STOCK NEWS: Earnings including SoftBank, Panasonic and Chubu Electric, China imposes duties on imports of Australian barley
content:
AUSTRALIA

James Hardie Industries (JHX AT) - Co. FY20 net AUD 241.5mln vs. Prev. AUD 228.8mln Y/Y, Co. is unable to provide guidance. (Newswires)

Nine Entertainment (NZM AT) - Interim injunction preserving exclusive negotiation period between Co. and NZME for Stuff NZ has been denied. (Newswires)

Tabcorp (TAH AT) - Co. announced agreement with lender for interest covenant waivers, while it will not pay a final dividend for FY20. (Newswires)

Village Roadshow (VRL AT) - PEP is said to have offered a deal prior to the BGH proposal made yesterday. (Newswires)

Westgold Resources (WGX AT) - Co. is expected to announce a capital raising to fund expansion plan in WA. (Newswires)

Westpac (WBC AT) - Co. retail banking chief Lindberg and Chief Information Officer Bright are to leave the Co. (Newswires)

Energy - WTI crude futures finished electronic trade higher by over 11%. (Newswires)

Other News - Chinese Commerce Ministry said it will levy anti-dumping duties on barley imports from Australia from May 19th. Australia Trade Minister Birmingham stated China’s decision to impose the tariffs is deeply disturbing, while the Agriculture Minister said the country will consider going to the WTO regarding the barley tariffs imposed by China. (Newswires)

 

JAPAN

Asahi Glass (5201 JT) - Co. Q1 net JPY 13.5bln vs. Prev. JPY 15.6bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Chubu Electric (9502 JT) - Co. FY net JPY 163.5bln vs. Prev. JPY 79.4bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Kaneka Corp (4118 JT) - Co. FY net JPY 14.0bln vs. Prev. JPY 22.0bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Komatsu (6301 JT) - Co. FY net JPY 153.8bln vs. Prev. JPY 256.5bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

NGK Insulators (5333 JT) - Co. FY net JPY 27.1bln vs. Prev. JPY 35.5bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Nomura Real Estate (3462 JT) - Co. is to secure new debt financing to repay existing JPY 15.8bln outstanding debt. (Newswires)

Panasonic (6752 JT) - Co. FY net JPY 225.7bln vs. Prev. JPY 284.2bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

SoftBank (9984 JT) - Co. FY net loss JPY 961.6bln vs. Prev. profit JPY 1.41tln Y/Y, rev. JPY 6.2tln vs. Prev. JPY 6.1tln Y/Y, maintains dividend at JPY 22/Shr with FY total dividend at JPY 44/Shr, but does not provide a forecast. Co. founder and CEO Son said they may not pay a dividend for the current year and will tap stake in Alibaba to raise USD 11.5bln of funds, while the Co. reportedly to sell a sizeable part of T-Mobile (TMUS) stake in a secondary offering according to sources. (Newswires/Nikkei/CNBC)

Sony (6758 JT) - Co. and Microsoft (MSFT) partner on smart camera solutions. (Newswires)

Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group (8316 JT) - Co. plans to lower strategic holdings by JPY 300bln over next 5 years. (Newswires)

Sumitomo Rubber Industries (5110 JT) - Co. Q1 net loss JPY 3.4bln vs. Prev. profit JPY 1.9bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Terumo (4543 JT) - Co. FY net JPY 85.2bln vs. Prev. JPY 79.5bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Utilities - Japan placed restrictions on foreign ownership of utilities. (Newswires)

Support - Japan’s LDP is considering JPY 10tln in financing for companies impacted by the virus, while it was separately reported that Tokyo will boost credit line for SMEs by JPY 1tln. (Jiji/Nikkei)

Other News - Japan is reportedly considering stating that the economy entered into a recession, while there were comments from Finance Minister Aso that Q2 GDP will also likely be severe. (Newswires/Nikkei)

 

SOUTH KOREA

Airlines - South Korean airlines will not apply fuel surcharges in international routes to reflect oil prices. (Yonhap)

Unemployment - South Korea unemployment reached a record high during the first 4 months of the year with around 2.08mln unemployed during the period. (Yonhap)

Other News - South Korean Finance Minister Hong said they will devise measures to encourage firms to bolster investment with the country drawing up a 3rd extra budget. (Yonhap)

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
CORONAVIRUS UPDATE / RESPONSES

US President Trump said extending the PPP time frame for the funds to be used "should be easy" and that the administration is mulling an "explore America" tax credit. President Trump also commented that some "big announcements are coming" and have already come out on therapeutics and vaccines for the coronavirus. Furthermore, Trump noted that he will provide a statement to the WHO in the near future and criticized that it has done a sad job, while he added that WHO is a puppet of China and that he was considering reducing the US contribution to WHO to USD 40mln (currently around USD 400mln) but added that some felt that was too much. (Newswires)

White House spokesperson called China's USD 2bln pledge to the WHO a "token" to distract from China's failure to warn the world of what was coming and stated that China has a responsibility to give more to WHO in the wake of the crisis. (Newswires)

White House Advisor Hassett said the Administration ready to take more COVID-19 spending action if needed although the final size will differ from the House Democrat plan, while he added that it appears US-China deal is largely being adhered to and that tensions with China are high. (Newswires)

NY Governor Cuomo said the western New York region is set to reopen tomorrow and urged sports teams to reopen without fans, while New Jersey Governor Murphy permitted some additional outdoor activities to reopen as the coronavirus spread continues to abate and Texas Governor Abbot stated that bars can reopen with limited capacity from Friday. (Newswires)

US COVID-19 cases rose by 13,284 to 1,480,349 (Prev. 1,467,065) and death toll rose by 698 to 89,407. (Newswires)

UK COVID-19 death toll rose to 34,796 (Prev. 34,636) which was an increase of 160 vs. Prev. 170 increase and the case count rose by 2,684 vs. Prev. 3,142 increase. (Newswires)

Moderna (MRNA) announced positive interim Phase One data for its MRNA vaccine against the coronavirus. However, the trial was conducted across just eight patients and three of the eight patients who were on the highest doses, saw severe but not life-threatening side effects. Furthermore, Moderna expects Phase Three studies to begin in July. (Newswires)

 

ASIA-PAC

PBoC will cautiously control financial adjustments and will implement monetary policy, as well as macro prudent policy more creatively. (Newswires)

Chinese Premier Li Keqiang is expected to take a tougher stance on Hong Kong in his report to the National People's Congress, while Beijing is said to increasingly see Hong Kong as the weak link in China’s national security that could be exploited by Washington as Sino-US tensions hit fever pitch in the aftermath of the pandemic, according to sources. (SCMP)

Chinese Commerce Ministry said it will levy anti-dumping duties on barley imports from Australia from May 19th. (Newswires)

US Health Secretary Azar said there has been an "apparent attempt to conceal this outbreak by at least one member state", without providing any names. (Newswires)

Pentagon legislation aims to end reliance on China for rare earth minerals. Reports added that the proposed legislation would raise spending caps under the Defense Production Act with the government to spend up to USD 1.75bln on rare earth elements in munitions and missiles, USD 350mln for microelectronics and eliminate caps when it comes to hypersonic weapons, while the proposal was offered earlier this month for inclusion in the annual defense policy bill Congress has been drafting. (Defense News)

 

UK/EU

BoE's Tenreyro said MPC has not ruled out any policy tool and that it is her personal view that negative rates have had a positive impact in Europe, while she added there are some considerations that would be more specific to the UK. (Newswires)

UK-US round two of trade talks have been scheduled for June 15-22, while a UK official said round one talks were positive and constructive, with "significant emphasis" on supporting the post-pandemic recovery. Furthermore, the UK is said to have identified "mutually high ambition" for an agreement to cover services, investment and digital trade. (Newswires)

Germany and France have for the first-time proposed joint EU debt issuance. The nations have proposed a EUR 500bln recovery fund to give grants–not loans–to member states, while German Chancellor Merkel said that repayment would be over a long-time frame and that the aid package has a combined of EUR 3tln. (Newswires)

Italy is to offer state guarantees of up to EUR 19bln of new bonds that are issued by Italian banks, according to a draft paper. (Newswires)

ECB's de Cos said the COVID-19 shock will last longer than initially expected and that the ECB has to act to avoid fragmentation among EZ countries. (Newswires)

 

COMMODITIES

Chinese oil demand is reportedly nearly back to pre COVID-19 levels, according to sources. (Newswires)

 

US

Fed Chair Powell reiterated pledge to maintain near-zero rates until the economy has weathered the crisis and Fed will use full range of tools to support the economy, while he noted that the passage of CARES act in March is critical to Fed's ability to expand credit programmes to help the economy. (Newswires)

NEC Director Kudlow believes the US economy is starting to turn, while he added the demand for housing, gasoline and the Apple mobility index are looking better. (Newswires)

 

MARKET RECAP

The week started in risk on fashion, supported by news of economies reopening and progress on vaccines and treatments. Traders were also encouraged by remarks from Fed chair Powell over the weekend, although some desks argued the market was being selective in its reading. The risk complex got a further shot in the arm on headlines out of Europe, where the French and Germans proposed for the first time joint EZ issuance. In aggregate, the result has been a traditional risk-on, with equities rallying, the VIX easing back into contango, crude rallying, Treasuries bear steepening, and the dollar lower. Moderna (MRNA) announced positive interim Phase One data for its MRNA vaccine against COVID-19; three patients on the highest doses had severe but not life-threatening side effects. Note that the initial study was conducted across just eight participants. Phase III study is expected to start in July. Grubhub (GRUB) reportedly rebuffed Uber’s (UBER) latest offer of 1.9 UBER shares for each GRUB share but talks continue, according to WSJ citing sources. Disney (DIS) announced it is to partially reopen its Disney Springs entertainment and shopping site at its Florida resort. Alphabet (GOOG) is likely to receive antitrust lawsuits from the DoJ and a group of state attorney general with a case expected by summer, according to WSJ citing sources. Tesla (TSLA) reportedly told employees that a health official signed off on the safety measures taken at its factory as it restarted production. The latest 13-F filings can be found here. SPX +3.2% at 2953, NDQ +2% at 9332, DJIA +3.9% at 24,597.

The Treasury curve bear-steepened on Monday amid a risk-on tone that swept across major assets to kickstart the week; yields rose from 3bps at the front-end to 13bps in the long bond. The downside in USTs and EGBs began in European trade as value/cylical/’real-economy’ stocks found their footing, particularly after constructive Fed Chair Powell comments from the weekend, and the news on a successful Phase 1 study of Moderna’s COVID vaccination – the pedigree duration-sensitive stocks were underperformers. The back-up in yields sustained into the US session, with bullish flows sparse amid the surprise Franco-German announcement of proposals for joint Euro issuance (coronabonds), emboldening risk appetite further, as well as raising the probability of further supply for the sovereign markets – Wednesday’s USD 20bln 20-year auction draws nearer, too. Supply indigestion was also made worse after Pfizer served the IG market with a four tranche USD 4bln deal, as well as continued offerings from other corporates on both sides of the Atlantic. Furthermore, the Fed has tapered its weekly asset purchases by another USD 1bln per day; analysts question how much further the Fed can realistically taper given the record debt issuance and strained primary dealer balance sheets – the recent easing of the supplementary leverage ratio will have provided a much needed cash buffer for such. US T-note futures (M0) settle 23+ ticks lower at 138-19.

Newsquawk US Market Wrap - May 18th: Cyclical-led rally amid vaccine developments and coronabonds
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities up, Treasuries down, Dollar down, Crude up.
  • REARVIEW: MRNA release positive vaccine data; FR and GER propose recovery fund; Powell reiterates message; Tenreyo & Haldane do not rule out NIRP
  • COMING UP: Data: UK Unemployment, German ZEW, US Building Permits & Housing Starts. Event: RBA Minutes. Speakers: Fed’s Chair Powell, Kashkari & Rosengren, ECB’s Lane. Earnings: Home Depot, Walmart.

MARKET WRAP

The week started in risk on fashion, supported by news of economies reopening and progress on vaccines and treatments. Traders were also encouraged by remarks from Fed chair Powell over the weekend, although some desks argued the market was being selective in its reading. The risk complex got a further shot in the arm on headlines out of Europe, where the French and Germans proposed for the first time joint EZ issuance. In aggregate, the result has been a traditional risk-on, with equities rallying, the VIX easing back into contango, crude rallying, Treasuries bear steepening, and the dollar lower, which has helped cyclically focussed FX to rally (even the beaten GBP, though it lagged other risk-sensitive FX like AUD and NZD), as well as EMFX. Gold printed another YTD high, but has backed off. Most of today’s gains were from companies that have been heavily beaten up this year (small caps and value baskets are leading), the R2K had a solid performance for once, while the momentum/COVID-beneficiaries lagged. With that said, the ES rally itself stalled out around 2,950, short of the April high around 2,965; technicians say the latter would need to be topped to open the door to the 200dma just under 3,000. Ahead, although the bulk of earnings season is behind us, there are some key reports due from the likes of WMT, HD and NVDA this week which will offer timely insight into how major companies are faring now the initial downside from COVID has passed (see here for earnings trends in Q1). Additionally, traders will be attentive to commentary from the Fed chief Powell on Tuesday (primer here). Elsewhere, the focus continues to be on virus headlines and responses out of Europe.

VACCINE

Moderna (MRNA) announced positive interim Phase One data for its MRNA vaccine against the coronavirus which spurred risk appetite. However, the trial was conducted across just eight patients, and three of the eight patients who were on the highest doses, saw severe but not life-threatening side effects. Moderna expect Phase Three studies to begin in July. The eight participants who received low and medium doses of the vaccine candidate had blood levels of virus-fighting antibodies that were similar or more than those in recovered coronavirus patients. Elsewhere, Gilead (GILD) notes that initial authorisation from the EU medicines agency for its remdesivir could be announced in the upcoming days. Also, a CDC US COVID-19 antibody test, expected in June or July, is to test up to 325k people and will test samples from 25 metropolitan areas, including New York and Seattle.

NORTH AMERICA

US/CHINA: After the US last week made moves to restrict the supply of US semiconductor chips to Huawei without government approval, there has been little pass through in Asian FX markets at the start of the week, Citi notes, although there has been some volatility in Asian semis. Citi warns that "scope for Chinese retaliation is now a real risk on the horizon, with the country’s 'unreliable entity list' a possible method of targeting US companies," and speculates that China may use laws and rules like Cybersecurity Review Measures and Anti-monopoly Law to investigate and impose restrictions on US firms. "Most US companies included on China's 'unreliable entity list' may be small-sized firms such as US trading agencies, which will be pushed to the brink of collapse; that could serve as a 'first-level' warning to the US over the Huawei ban before adding bigger companies," Citi writes, citing reports in China's Global Times newspaper on Friday.

OFFICIALS: White House Economic Advisor Hassett stated the Administration ready to take more COVID-19 spending action if needed, though final size will differ from the House Democrat plan. Hassett added it appears US/China deal largely being adhered to, although tensions with China are high. When asked about Huawei, Hassett said the US is watching things closely. Fed has responded aggressively and will not probably have to do much more with interest rates if we become confident that a bottom has been reached. Elsewhere, Hassett noted credit card data is going up and the number of businesses open in the US is skyrocketing; things are moving forward faster than he initially thought. NEC Director Kudlow with a similar optimistic tone, believes the US economy is starting to turn, noting demand for housing, gasoline and Apple mobility index are looking better.

EUROPE

JOINT ISSUANCE: Germany and France have for the first-time proposed joint EU debt issuance, a pivotal moment in the bloc’s history. The nations have proposed a EUR 500bln recovery fund to give grants–not loans–to member states. Merkel said the combined aid package now has a volume of EUR 3trln. The bonds would be paid back via the EU national budget, German Chancellor Merkel said, and repayment would be over a long-time frame (Germany’s share would be 27%, as in the EU budget). National Parliaments will also have to give the green light; there is the possibility of an EU Treaty change in the long-term, but this proposal is focussed on the short-term. French President Macron said the proposals had been made in conjunction with consulting the likes of Italy and Netherlands (the latter has reportedly been against the idea, while the former is set to be a key beneficiary). There has already been some push-back from Austria, who want it to be funded through loans and not grants. The key takeaways, analysts initially said, was that the new EUR 500bln would be backed by the EU budget, not an ESM-style backing by member state guarantees Others noted while the size is still small when compared to, say US responses, the precedent is more of a positive development for the bloc that states can commonly issue debt to address problems the bloc faces. One analyst said that while this time it took a pandemic to force the move, in the future, the bar may be lower.

CENTRAL BANKS

FED CHAIR POWELL: There was nothing particularly new for market players in Fed Chair Powell’s Sunday evening remarks. The recent data metrics are clearly being overlooked for now, and Powell stressed that medical metrics were far more important for the US economy; elsewhere, as lawmakers on Capitol Hill debate a new round of stimulus, Powell suggested that at least three-to-six more months of government support would be required. There was a hint of optimism in some of Powell’s remarks: he said “if we are thoughtful and careful about how we reopen the economy so that people take these social distancing measures forward and try to do what we can not to have another outbreak... then the recovery can begin fairly soon,” adding that "assuming there is not a second wave of the coronavirus, I think you will see the economy recover steadily through the second half of this year,” and “for the economy to fully recover people will have to be fully confident and that may have to await the arrival of a vaccine.” The Fed chair also said that the Fed was not out of ammunition (“not by a long shot”) although again pushed-back on negative rates, and he is confident job losses would be temporary. Powell will testify to the Senate Banking Committee on Tuesday, and then speak at a Fed listens event on Thursday. The FOMC’s latest meeting minutes are also on the slate for Wednesday. Powell has spoken a few times in recent weeks, and it is unlikely the Fed chair will have anything new to offer, and as such, his comments are not likely to be a major risk for traders, analysts suggest.

POWELL TESTIMONY PRIMER: This week’s testimony by Chair Powell on Tuesday, the meeting minutes from the FOMC’s April confab on Wednesday, and the Fed Listens event to be attended by Powell on Thursday are not likely to reveal much by way of new information, given the proximity of the recent meeting and the subsequent commentary from Fed Chair Powell. Accordingly, the message from these events is likely to be a reiteration that the Fed will take action it deems necessary towards supporting the economy and aiding its bounce back from COVID, although that is not likely to include negative rates at this stage; the Fed is also likely to again call on fiscal authorities to help with the heavy lifting. Click here to access our primer.

BOE: BOE chief economist Haldane on the weekend said that the bank was considering a number of policies, including negative rates and boosting asset purchases to include other assets, as conventional room to ease was running low. Haldane emphasised that there were not imminent plans to implement these policies. Tenreyo also spoke on negative rates stating they are not ruled out, nor is any policy tool, and that she believes that negative rates had a positive effect in Europe, but there are some considerations that would be more specific to the UK. Haldane’s comments follow those of BOE Governor Bailey last week, who also did not want to rule out the policy for future use, and the theme will stay in vogue when BOE Governor Bailey delivers his testimony to the Treasury on Wednesday. The Old Lady is expected to boost the size of its QE programme at its next policy meeting, analysts believe, so any indications of the size the asset purchase programme will be raised by are also of interest (a consensus is developing around GBP 200bln-ish).

ECB: Chief Economist Lane stated the ECB is constantly assessing whether we are doing enough and that the size/duration of its purchases can be adjusted, reiterating comments from President Lagarde. ECB’s de Cos stated the COVID-19 shock will last longer than expected. He also reiterated other officials that the ECB has to act to avoid fragmentation, noting that the response from Europe to the pandemic has been insufficient; the comments took place before Merkel and Macron agreed to propose a EUR 500bln fund in grants and proposed joint debt. President Lagarde welcomed the welcomed the Franco-German "ambitious and targeted" proposal for an EU recovery fund, and noted there is no risk to the Euro, the currency is irreversible.

FIXED INCOME

US T-NOTE FUTURES (M0) SETTLE 23+ TICKS LOWER AT 138-19

The Treasury curve bear-steepened on Monday amid a risk-on tone that swept across major assets to kickstart the week; yields rose from 3bps at the front-end to 13bps in the long bond. The downside in USTs and EGBs began in European trade as value/cylical/’real-economy’ stocks found their footing, particularly after constructive Fed Chair Powell comments from the weekend, and the news on a successful Phase 1 study of Moderna’s COVID vaccination – the pedigree duration-sensitive stocks were underperformers. The back-up in yields sustained into the US session, with bullish flows sparse amid the surprise Franco-German announcement of proposals for joint Euro issuance (coronabonds), emboldening risk appetite further, as well as raising the probability of further supply for the sovereign markets – Wednesday’s USD 20bln 20-year auction draws nearer, too. Supply indigestion was also made worse after Pfizer served the IG market with a four tranche USD 4bln deal, as well as continued offerings from other corporates on both sides of the Atlantic. Furthermore, the Fed has tapered its weekly asset purchases by another USD 1bln per day; analysts question how much further the Fed can realistically taper given the record debt issuance and strained primary dealer balance sheets – the recent easing of the supplementary leverage ratio will have provided a much needed cash buffer for such.

CRUDE

WTI (M0) SETTLED USD 2.39 HIGHER AT USD 31.82; WTI (N0) SETTLED USD 2.13 HIGHER AT USD 31.65; BRENT (N0) SETTLES USD 2.31 HIGHER AT USD 34.81

Crude rallied at the start of the week, amid a more constructive backdrop for the demand-side of the equation; analysts noted that economies reopening and restrictions are relaxed is a positive development, and analysts have pointed to news reports like those from India, where fuel demand has recovered off April lows, and in China, where some reports have stated that demand is back to around the 13mln BPD level. On the supply side, there remains encouragement after last week’s inventory builds, and hopes that the overhang of global inventories will soon face draws; additionally, tracking estimates by Petro-Logistics suggests that OPEC+ exports will drop by a huge 5.96mkn BPD in the first 13 days of May v April averages. Analysts at Citi also cited some technical factors for today’s oil moves, noting that a “technical squeeze that has wedged nearby June WTI futures to a backwardation premium over the July contract ahead of Tuesday’s contract expiration, and that the nearby tightness has emerged after ETF, index fund and other traders fled the June contract three weeks ago to avoid a repeat of the May contract collapse into negative territory.” But Citi retains a hint of pessimism and still believes that there is a surplus of crude oil and products in the system, including excess diesel fuel from Asian refiners which is said to be bound for Europe, as well as Saudi crude heading towards the US. “For all of the large swings in both supply and demand, we doubt the physical market has actually flipped from glut to shortage in a blink,” the bank writes, “only the paper market has.” Note that US President Trump asserted his optimism in the complex, tweeting today, “OIL (ENERGY) IS BACK!!!!”.

DATA

NAHB HOUSING MARKET INDEX (MAY): The housing market index rose from 30.0 to 37.0, above analyst expectations of 35.0. Albeit a beat and a rise, the index remains at levels seen in 2012 after its recent steep decline. Pantheon Macroeconomics believes there is scope for it to rise further over the next few months, and it highlights how mortgage applications have recovered over half the drop, while Google searches for “new home” are above the pre-virus peak. Sales over the next 6-months increased by 10.0 points to 46, the May data showed, while present sales ticked up to 42.0 from 36.0. Traffic of prospective buyers rose 8 points to 21.0. Pantheon believes “that the pool of potential homebuyers has shrunk by much less than the drop in payrolls, because the first big wave of layoffs was concentrated in sectors where most employees are relatively young, and low paid.”

EQUITIES

CLOSING LEVELS: SPX +3.2% at 2953, NDQ +2% at 9332, DJIA +3.9% at 24,597

SECTORS: Energy +7.6%, Industrials +6.6%, Financials +5.3%, Real Estate +4.9%, Materials +4.6%, Utilities +4.1%, Discretionary +3.2%, Technology +2.6%, Communications +2.1%, Consumer Staples +1.7%, Health Care +0.9%

STOCK SPECIFICS: Moderna (MRNA) announced positive interim Phase One data for its MRNA vaccine against COVID-19; three patients on the highest doses had severe but not life-threatening side effects. Note that the initial study was conducted across just eight participants. Phase III study is expected to start in July. Grubhub (GRUB) reportedly rebuffed Uber’s (UBER) latest offer of 1.9 UBER shares for each GRUB share but talks continue, according to WSJ citing sources. Disney (DIS) announced it is to partially reopen its Disney Springs entertainment and shopping site at its Florida resort. Alphabet (GOOG) is likely to receive antitrust lawsuits from the DoJ and a group of state attorney general with a case expected by summer, according to WSJ citing sources. Tesla (TSLA) reportedly told employees that a health official signed off on the safety measures taken at its factory as it restarted production. The latest 13-F filings can be found here.

FX WRAP

USD, EUR: The greenback was slammed amid favourable risk conditions, falling from 100.47 at the highs to 99.58 at the lows as a combination of vaccine and bounce back hopes while economies are starting to reopen. The news set the tone for the day. Downside was exacerbated by gains in the EUR after German Chancellor Merkel and French President Macron agreed on the need for a EUR 500bln coronavirus fund in grants, not loans and both agreed to propose joint EU debt issuance. The news saw EUR among FX outperformers seeing EURUSD back above 1.09 to highs of 1.0926 from lows of 1.0801.

CYCLICALS: Risk friendly currencies performed well today amid a tumbling dollar as risk sentiment was buoyed on vaccine hopes and reopening of the economy seeing solid performance in AUD, NZD & CAD, however GBP, albeit still firmer, is lagging due to dovish central bank commentary. The looney caught another tailwind due to the rally in crude, USD selling, and the improved risk appetite, the trifecta saw USDCAD back beneath 1.40 from 1.4116 after the reopen of electronic trade.

GBP: Despite high-beta/cyclical FX starting the week on the front-foot, Sterling is lagging after BOE chief economist Haldane on the weekend said that the bank was considering a number of policies, including negative rates and boosting asset purchases to include other assets, as conventional room to ease was running low. Haldane emphasised that there were not imminent plans to implement these policies. Tenreyo also spoke on negative rates stating they are not ruled out and that she believes that negative rates had a positive effect in Europe. Haldane’s comments follow those of BOE Governor Bailey last week, who also did not want to rule out the policy for future use, and the theme will stay in vogue when BOE Governor Bailey delivers his testimony to the Treasury on Wednesday. The Old Lady is expected to boost the size of its QE programme at its next policy meeting, analysts believe, so any indications of the size the asset purchase programme will be raised by are also of interest (a consensus is developing around GBP 200bln-ish). Sterling is also facing headwinds as Brexit negotiations resume. And on the data slate, there is tier one releases due this week; SocGen says bears will not need much encouragement to lower short-term targets for the pound if the trio of first-tier UK data disappoint this week, starting with employment tomorrow and ending with retail sales on Friday.

CHF: SNB’s Maechler on the weekend said the central bank was intervening intensively in FX to shield the Swiss economy, noting that the pressure on the CHF has risen considerably. She argued that the rise of CHF versus the EUR would have been much more pronounced if the SNB had not been prepared to intervene more heavily. Maechler said that Switzerland was unlikely to see a slim v-shaped recovery. CHF has been lingering around 1.05, though Maechler said the SNB had not got any formal or informal upper band for the level of the currency, stating that it looks at the entire currency situation. However, Maechler said that the central bank bought stocks during the turmoil in March in order to maintain around 20% of its reserves invested in equities. Maechler also dismissed the notion of a bigger payout to the government from the profits the central bank generates, stating that it would contravene the SNB’s monetary policy. Goldman Sachs notes that sight deposits have increased for 17 weeks in a row, and are now CHF 85bln higher than at the start of the year, and FX reserve data show a similar picture. “As a result, the currency is trading much weaker than fundamentals would suggest,” GS writes, “with the currency facing persistent pressures, the SNB will need to weigh the costs of a mounting balance sheet.” GS continues to recommend short EURCHF targeting 1.02 in 3-months.

JPY: Japanese GDP came in slightly better than expected overnight, printing -0.9% Q/Q against the consensus -1.2%, meaning that Japan’s economy has now fallen into recession. All major components were lower, and analysts warn that it might be worse ahead, with COVID presenting challenges regarding the impact of the virus to trade and the domestic economy, UOB said. “The real test of the severity of the COVID-19 driven GDP contraction will be in the current quarter, 2Q 2020,” the bank writes, “we have further revised our forecast of the 2Q contraction to be more severe, at -5% Q/Q; this is slightly worse than the sharpest contraction Japan experienced during the great recession in 2008/2009.” With markets facing a risk friendly environment today the JPY traded weaker against a falling dollar and remained within the 107.05-107.50 parameters.

GOLD: The yellow metal has printed fresh YTD highs at the start of the week, supported by technicals, falling real rates, while US/China tensions has also kept gold in demand. Many desks are now talking about a move towards USD 1,800. Today’s price action was however quite choppy after the precious metal saw highs of 1764, although as equities rallied and risk sentiment was bolstered, gold entered negative territory to intraday lows of 1728.

AUD: The RBA meeting minutes due overnight are not expected to be a game changer, and RBC says that the minutes have largely been superseded by the quarterly SOMP, which provided some updated forecasts on a number of key variables: GDP, inflation, and unemployment through to mid‐2022 as well some alternative scenarios. RBC says “any discussion around its unconventional policy is likely to repeat a willingness to ‘scale up’ bond buying if needed.”

EMFX: Positive risk sentiment saw EM perform very well with outperformance in the BRL, while MXN and RUB caught a tailwind from the solid gains in crude prices, which in turn likely prevented gains in TRY; which was the relative EMFX underperformer today. The BRL saw solid gains against the falling buck today as President Bolsonaro continues to push towards an economic reopening. However, after its latest health minister resigned (after his predecessor was fired) political worries in Brazil continue to overhang. Elsewhere, HSBC highlight reports that the federal police tipped off President Bolsonaro’s son that they were to open an investigation into his former aide. HSBC remains BRL bearish, noting it recently adjusted its year-end target to 6.20.

subject: ECB President Lagarde welcomes the Franco-German "ambitious and targeted" proposal for an EU recovery fund
analysis_details:
Lagarde has constantly noted that the EZ needs to do more from the fiscal side, and she seems pleased with this latest proposal. 

Earlier, Germany and France have for the first-time proposed joint EU debt issuance, a pivotal moment in the bloc’s history. The nations have proposed a EUR 500bln recovery fund to give grants–not loans–to member states. Merkel said the combined aid package now has a volume of EUR 3trln. The bonds would be paid back via the EU national budget, German Chancellor Merkel said, and repayment would be over a long-time frame (Germany’s share would be 27%, as in the EU budget). National Parliaments will also have to give the green light; there is the possibility of an EU Treaty change in the long-term, but this proposal is focussed on the short-term. French President Macron said the proposals had been made in conjunction with consulting the likes of Italy and Netherlands (the latter has reportedly been against the idea, while the former is set to be a key beneficiary). There has already been some push-back from Austria, who want it to be funded through loans and not grants. The key takeaways, analysts initially said, was that the new EUR 500bln would be backed by the EU budget, not an ESM-style backing by member state guarantees Others noted while the size is still small when compared to, say US responses, the precedent is more of a positive development for the bloc that states can commonly issue debt to address problems the bloc faces. One analyst said that while this time it took a pandemic to force the move, in the future, the bar may be lower.

analysis_details: The Treasury curve bear-steepened on Monday amid a risk-on tone that swept across major assets to kickstart the week; yields rose from 3bps at the front-end to 13bps in the long bond. The back-up in yields sustained into the US session, with bullish flows sparse amid the surprise Franco-German announcement of proposals for joint Euro issuance (coronabonds), emboldening risk appetite further, as well as raising the probability of further supply for the sovereign markets – Wednesday’s USD 20bln 20-year auction draws nearer, too. Supply indigestion was also made worse after Pfizer served the IG market with a four tranche USD 4bln deal, as well as continued offerings from other corporates on both sides of the Atlantic. Furthermore, the Fed has tapered its weekly asset purchases by another USD 1bln per day; analysts question how much further the Fed can realistically taper given the record debt issuance and strained primary dealer balance sheets – the recent easing of the supplementary leverage ratio will have provided a much needed cash buffer for such.

ANALYSIS: NAHB housing index surprised to the upside in May; may be scope to rise further in months ahead, Pantheon Macroeconomics said
analysis_details: The housing market index rose from 30.0 to 37.0, above analyst expectations of 35.0. Albeit a beat and a rise, the index remains at levels seen in 2012 after its recent steep decline. Pantheon Macroeconomics believes there is scope for it to rise further over the next few months, and it highlights how mortgage applications have recovered over half the drop, while Google searches for “new home” are above the pre-virus peak. Sales over the next 6-months increased by 10.0 points to 46, the May data showed, while present sales ticked up to 42.0 from 36.0. Traffic of prospective buyers rose 8 points to 21.0. Pantheon believes “that the pool of potential homebuyers has shrunk by much less than the drop in payrolls, because the first big wave of layoffs was concentrated in sectors where most employees are relatively young, and low paid.”

subject: SNAP ANALYSIS: Germany and France have for the first-time proposed joint EU debt issuance, a pivotal moment in the bloc’s history
analysis_details:
PROPOSAL: Germany and France have for the first-time proposed joint EU debt issuance, a pivotal moment in the bloc’s history. The nations have proposed a EUR 500bln recovery fund to give grants–not loans–to member states. Merkel said the combined aid package now has a volume of EUR 3trln. The bonds would be paid back via the EU national budget, German Chancellor Merkel said, and repayment would be over a long-time frame (Germany’s share would be 27%, as in the EU budget). National Parliaments will also have to give the green light; there is the possibility of an EU Treaty change in the long-term, but this proposal is focussed on the short-term. French President Macron said the proposals had been made in conjunction with consulting the likes of Italy and Netherlands (the latter has reportedly been against the idea, while the former is set to be a key beneficiary).

SNAP ANALYSIS: The key takeaways, analysts initially said, was that the new EUR 500bln would be backed by the EU budget, not an ESM-style backing by member state guarantees Others noted while the size is still small when compared to, say US responses, the precedent is more of a positive development for the bloc that states can commonly issue debt to address problems the bloc faces. One analyst said that while this time it took a pandemic to force the move, in the future, the bar may be lower.

MARKET REACTION: The market has taken this as a big positive, and risk has continued to rally in wake of the announcement; however, ES topped out around 2950, short of the April high at 2965; EUR, meanwhile, is struggling to vault 1.09 with any degree of conviction.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: phase 1 vaccine positivity outweighs pandemic, economic and trade negativity
content:
USD

The Dollar is broadly softer amidst heightened risk appetite fuelled by the ongoing recovery in crude prices into Tuesday’s June WTI expiry that is also boosting Brent, while news that Moderna’s MRNA anti-coronavirus vaccine achieved positive interim trial results has also boosted sentiment at the start of a new week. As such, the DXY lost 100.000+ status again or at least has ducked under to 99.688 vs 100.470 at best, and the Greenback is lower vs EM as well as all major counterparts bar the Yen.

NZD/AUD

Already firmly on the rebound, the Kiwi eclipsed its Antipodean peer in the race to reclaim 0.6000 vs 0.6500 against the Buck, and accordingly the Aud/Nzd cross is back below 1.0800 from 1.0900 at one stage. NZ PPI looms, while the Aussie awaits RBA minutes and is coming to terms with China’s 80% tariff on barley that Australia’s Trade Minister describes as deeply disappointing.

NOK/GBP/CAD/SEK

The next best G10 currencies, as the Norwegian Crown derives more momentum from oil to retest recent peaks beyond 11.0000 against the Euro and Sterling claws back more post-BoE Haldane declines in Eur/Gbp cross terms through 0.8900 and with Cable back over 1.2200 compared to circa 1.2075 at worst eyeing further MPC comments via Tenreyro, though not mentioning NIRP like Haldane over the weekend. Elsewhere, the Loonie has now extended its crude inspired revival by more than a big figure from around 1.4116 ahead of Tuesday’s Canadian house price data and the Swedish Krona is being carried by risk-on flows to around 10.6000 vs the single currency even though the Labour Market Board see unemployment at nearly 8.5% in mid-May.

EUR/CHF 

Also firmer relative to the Dollar on the aforementioned pick-up in risk positioning, with Eur/Usd bouncing from 1.0800 to 1.0890+ following a further slowing in Eurozone COVID-19 cases and fatalities as member states re-open and reports that France and Germany are both now backing joint EU debt issuance. Meanwhile, Usd/Chf is back beneath 0.9700 from 0.9730+ in contrast to Eur/Chf holding above 1.0500 and last week’s new almost 5 year lows closer to the round number that the SNB denies forms any kind of tolerance limit. 

JPY/XAU

Monday’s laggards on a general unwinding of safe-haven premium, as the Yen gradually lost ground against the Greenback from 107.05 to 107.50, but not quite in time to trigger 2.2 bn expiry interest at the half round number for the NY cut, while Gold pared back from Usd 1760+ through Usd 1750 and stops on a break of Usd 1743 to sub-Usd 1730.

EM

Broad appreciation vs the Usd, but the commodity currencies doing particularly well and the Lira not suffering due to considerably higher imported crude costs as Try liquidity dried up to the extent that 2 big clearing platforms ceased trading.

French President Macron says for the first time France and Germany are proposing for EU to raise debt jointly
analysis_details:
• This follows comments from Merkel who stated we need an EU recovery fund with both Macron and Merkel noting it should be EUR 500bln in grants. The grants had been a request from those harder hit members in the previous negotiations, therefore this move will likely be welcomed by the southern states, although a response from other northern members is awaited.
  • Last month, EU leaders failed to come to an agreement on its recovery crisis package. Heading into that meeting there was a continued divide between Northern and Southern states on whether it should be financed through grants or loans; Spain & Italy called for grants to avoid raising debt levels. Some had pointed towards June or July to find more clarity on what is needed, despite some of the worst hit regions (Italy, Spain, France) calling for an imminent response; Macron after called for a quick and strong response worth 5-10% of GDP, noting “Europe has no future if a response cannot be found to this exceptional shock”. French President Macron noted the issue was not with mutualised debt, but solely on grants or loans; although now it seems debt negotiations will continue while Germany seems in favour of using the grants instead of loans.

subject: US EQUITY OPEN: Stocks rally to start the week on vaccine & bounce back hopes as economies start to reopen
analysis_details:
SNAPSHOT: US equities open with solid gains, and the VIX is under 30; the NDX is underperforming, however; the Treasury curve is steeper, with yields higher across the curve ahead of this week’s new 20-year bond auction; the DXY is down, and gold continues to find YTD highs, albeit off highs; positive risk sentiment is supporting crude. The risk-on start to the week is being attributed to positive vaccine updates from Moderna (MRNA), optimism on economies reopening (California is now 75% reopened, its Governor said; tech giant AAPL is also planning to reopen more stores) and hopes of a bounce back (Powell on the weekend said we could see a steady recovery in H2, and that the central bank was not out of ammo). Analysts do now seem to be asking the question of how policymakers will respond if there is a second wave. Stocks in Asia and Europe were higher, although there was caution around Asian semis after US moves aimed at Huawei last week. Some, this morning, have warned that traders are taking a selective approach to the news, and ignoring some of the more ‘risk-off’ items.

SECTORS: All sectors open in positive territory with risk appetite bolstered by positive COVID vaccine updates from Moderna (MRNA). Energy outperforms as it tracks firmer crude prices, industrials also performing well, +~5%. Consumer Staples and Communication Services underperform with the latter weighed on by losses in Google (GOOG) after reports it is expected to receive a number of antitrust lawsuits.

STOCK SPECIFICS: Moderna (MRNA) announced positive interim Phase One data for its MRNA vaccine against COVID-19; three patients on the highest doses had severe but not life-threatening side effects. Note that the initial study was conducted across just eight participants. Phase III study is expected to start in July. Grubhub (GRUB) reportedly rebuffed Uber’s (UBER) latest offer of 1.9 UBER shares for each GRUB share but talks continue, according to WSJ citing sources. Disney (DIS) announced it is to partially reopen its Disney Springs entertainment and shopping site at its Florida resort. Alphabet (GOOG) is likely to receive antitrust lawsuits from the DoJ and a group of state attorney general with a case expected by summer, according to WSJ citing sources. Tesla (TSLA) reportedly told employees that a health official signed off on the safety measures taken at its factory as it restarted production. The latest 13-F filings can be found here.

Q1 EARNINGS SEASON KEY THEMES: Goldman Sachs has four observations from Q1 earnings reports: 1) S&P 500 earnings are partially insulated relative to the economy given its large-cap tilt and high weight in non-cyclical industries. Concentration within the equity market has been growing, and while S&P 500 EPS was -14% in Q1, Russell 2000 EPS was -90%. 2) Online platforms and shifting business models will partially offset the revenue declines in in-person consumption, and restrictions have expedited the shift to e-commerce and other online services. 3) The increased costs associated with maintaining or resuming business activity will continue to pressure profit margins, particularly at bricks and mortar corporates. 4) Several companies noted that revenue declines stabilized in April and there were pockets of improvement in early Q2, but the bank warns that while this nascent improvement is encouraging, it likely partially reflects the direct consumer payments under the CARES Act, which may prove temporary. Ahead: GS says understanding the actual pace of economic activity in 2020 will be critical to sizing the downside risk to S&P 500 EPS estimates. The bank maintains its FY 2020 S&P 500 EPS view of USD 110 (-33% Y/Y) and USD 170 for FY21, but adjusts its quarterly path of earnings growth downwards in Q3 and Q4. Looking beyond 2020, GS says investors will remain focused on how quickly lost earnings can be recouped. More here.

DAMPENING VOL: Last week, VIX started off sub-30, saw a high of 40 amid equity downside, before closing out the week in the low 30s. Morgan Stanley has recently argued that three factors are helping to dampen volatility: 1) health care advances; President Trump’s “Operation Warp Speed” feeds into this, with the programme aiming to speed the development of a vaccine via simultaneous testing of different candidates and beginning production before they’ve cleared clinical trials, with hopes of delivering a fully approved vaccine by the end of 2020. 2) monetary policy, which has been quick to respond to COVID, and has over-delivered, backstopping the downside in equities. 3) fiscal policy; while we have seen 3.5 tranches of aid thus far, lawmakers are split on the next package. MS public policy strategists think lawmakers can come together and deliver one more dose of fiscal stimulus, and then hold-off further measures until the November election. The bank’s base case for ‘CARES Part 2’ is for an extension of USD 700bn-1.1trln, while its bull case is for a USD 1.6-2.4trln. However, others note that there does not appear to be any firm consensus on Capitol Hill, and last week, traders noted that Fed Chair Powell again put the onus on fiscal policymakers to deliver more.

V-SHAPE AND INFLATION: Many have become sceptical about the notion of a V-shaped economic recovery in the US, however, Morgan Stanley’s equity strategists do, noting that uncertainty is always high in recession, but that a V shape is what history tells us to expect. The bank also notes that many investors are talking about inflation again, and although it may be too early to put the inflation trade on in full today, MS strategists believe that rate sensitive stocks, cyclicals, and small caps tend to show the highest correlation to inflation expectations, while bond proxies and defensive names display the lowest. In the short term, MS still thinks the market needs a breather to work-off some overbought conditions, which it says is a necessary step before resuming a secular bull market. “While concentration is evident in the SPX, it is not alone in driving the market higher,” the bank says, arguing that “pullbacks will provide a good entry point, especially as stock specific risk starts to improve.” The key question, therefore, is how inflationary any rebound will be, and MS says two factors suggest inflation could be in the pipeline: COVID recession will be shorter than GFC, and policymakers response has been quicker and more emphatic. More here.

Newsquawk Daily US Equity Opening News - May 18th, 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Apple Inc. (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) and Alphabet Inc Class C (GOOG) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) are reportedly seeing Europe align itself with their latest coronavirus tracking app.
  • Moderna (MRNA) (Health Care/Biotechnology) announced positive interim Phase One data for its MRNA vaccine against COVID-19; three patients on the highest doses had severe but not life-threatening side effects. Note that the initial study was conducted across just eight participants Phase III study is expected to start in July.
  • Uber (UBER) (Industrials/Road&Rail) and Grubhub (GRUB) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) – GRUB reportedly rebuffed UBER’s latest offer of 1.9 UBER shares for each GRUB share but talks continue, according to WSJ citing sources.

Note, a list of the latest 13-F filings can be found at the bottom of the Daily US Equity Opening News.

This week’s Barron’s articles highlight it is too early to choose the winners from COVID-19, although when it comes to vaccines, it notes that Pfizer (PFE) holds a strong position although there are risks with the smaller biotech names like Moderna (MRNA, Novavax (NVAX) and Inovio (INO). Elsewhere on 5G, it notes that the carriers (VZ, T) could see a delay to their potential rewards, although in the near term it is best to play the 5G move through 5G investment companies (NOK, ERIC, SSNLF, ZTCOY, HUAWEI) which are to provide antennas and base stations. The author adds a benefit will follow through to Cisco (CSCO), Juniper (JNPR), Ciena (CIEN, and Corning (GLW). On Cisco (CSCO) it writes that it still matters despite a “terrible earnings report”, while it suggests ViacomCBS (VIAC) could benefit from the pandemic as it sees faster streaming growth. On dividends, Barron’s write that Verizon (VZ), Procter & Gamble (PG), Johnson & Johnson (JNJ), Comcast (CMCSA), Merck (MRK), McDonald's (MCD), PepsiCo (PEP), and Medtronic (MDT) have the potential to sustain or grow their dividends. The authors elsewhere suggest Wayfair (W) could fall 25% as the economy reopens after it soared during the lockdown periods.

Of note for Video Gaming names (ATVI, EA, TTWO), consumer spending on games hit a new record of USD 10.86bln in Q1, according to The NPD group.

DOW JONES

  • Apple Inc. (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) and Alphabet Inc Class C (GOOG) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) are reportedly seeing Europe align itself with their latest coronavirus tracking app.
  • Apple Inc. (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) announced it is to reopen over 25 stores across the US.
  • The Walt Disney Company (DIS) (Communication Services/Movies & Entertainment) announced it is to partially reopen its Disney Springs entertainment and shopping site at its Florida resort.

NASDAQ 100

  • Alphabet Inc Class C (GOOG) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) is likely to receive antitrust lawsuits from the DoJ and a group of state attorney general with a case expected by summer, according to WSJ citing sources.
  • Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) announced it has plans to reopen its warehouses in France from next week after it resolved a dispute over working conditions with unions, according to WSJ.
  • Biogen Inc. (BIIB) (Health Care/Biotechnology) announced additional data from its SPINRAZA programme that further demonstrated sustained efficacy and long term safety of the drug in patients with spinal muscular atrophy.
  • Gilead Sciences (GILD) (Health Care/Biotechnology) initial authorisation from the EU medicines agency for remdesivir could come in the upcoming days.
  • Tesla (TSLA) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) reportedly told employees that a health official signed off on the safety measures taken at its factory as it restarted production.
  • T-Mobile (TMUS) (Communication Services/Wireless Telecommunication Services) – SoftBank is reportedly in discussion to sell a large part of its stake in the co. to Deutsche Telekom (DTEGY, DTE GY) to raise funds.
  • Zoom Video Communications (ZM) (Information Technology/Software) announced it is investigating the root cause of issues joining Zoom Meetings. Meanwhile Google Meet (GOOG) reached over 50mln installs on the Play Store, according to Android Police.

S&P 500

  • General Motors (GM) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobile Manufacturers) is reportedly planning to restart its Mexico plant in Silao on May 20th, according to a letter.
  • Legg Mason (LM) (Financials/Capital Markets) announced its shareholders have approved its merger proposal with Franklin Resources (BEN) (Financials/Capital Markets).
  • Occidental Petroleum (OXY) (Energy/Oil & Gas Exploration & Production) Algeria asset sale to Total (TOT, FP FP) has been discontinued and Total have decided not to pursue the purchase of its Ghana assets. Although it has completed the sale of its Mozambique and South Africa assets to Total.
  • PerkinElmer (PKI) (Health Care/Health Care Equipment) is reportedly being probed in a Federal investigation for alleged Medicare fraud regarding "tens of thousands of unnecessary genetic cancer tests" according to sources.
  • Thermo Fisher Scientific (TMO) (Health Care/Health Care Equipment) published its offer documents for a voluntary tender offer for all Qiagen (QGEN) (Health Care/Life Sciences Tools & Services) shares. Elsewhere, TMO received a US government contract to provide Viral Transport Media (VTM) for COVID-19 sample collection
  • Under Armour Class A (UAA) (Consumer Discretionary/Apparel, Accessories & Luxury Goods) has named Mohamed El-Erian as a lead independent director.

OTHER

  • BWX Technologies (BWXT) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) received a USD 13bln Tank Closure Contract from the DoE over 10 years.
  • Camping World (CWH) (Consumer Discretionary/Specialty Retail) announced it has declared a cash dividend of USD 0.1532/shr, while it also declared a cash distribution of USD 0.08/unit on CWGS Enterprises.
  • Forescout (FSCT) (Information Technology/Software) – Advent announced it would not be going ahead with its acquisition of the co. Note, Spruce Point Capital is short FSCT and expects it is worth in the teens at best.
  • GSX Techedu (GSX) (Consumer Discretionary/Diversified Consumer Services) is a new short position at Muddy Waters (GSX is already a short at Citron) as it is a “massive fraud – a Zero.” Muddy Waters suspect at least 80% of its revenue is fake and possibly even 90%+.
  • Hertz (HTZ) (Industrials/Road&Rail) CEO Marinello is to step down with Paul Stone to become President and CEO, effective immediately. Stone was an executive VP and Chief Retail Operations officer at Hertz.
  • JC Penney (JCP) (Consumer Discretionary/Multiline Retail) filed for its Chapter 11 bankruptcy plan, JCP holds roughly USD 500mln in cash and has received commitments for USD 900mln in debtor-in-possession financing.
  • Moderna (MRNA) (Health Care/Biotechnology) announced positive interim Phase One data for its MRNA vaccine against COVID-19; three patients on the highest doses had severe but not life-threatening side effects. Note that the initial study was conducted across just eight participants Phase III study is expected to start in July.
  • Sea Ltd (SE) (Communication Services/Entertainment) Q1 20 (USD): EPS -0.61 (exp. -0.33), Revenue 714mln (exp. 910mln).
  • Taiwan Semiconductor (TSM) (Information Technology/Semiconductors & Semiconductor Equipment) has reportedly stopped new orders from Huawei after the move from Washington to limit chip supplies to Huawei. Elsewhere, DigiTimes report that a Foxconn/TSM collaboration in the US would not be surprising, according to sources.
  • Teva Pharmaceuticals (TEVA) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) announced the China National Medical Products Administration approved its AUSTEDO for the treatment of chorea associated with Huntington’s Disease.
  • Uber (UBER) (Industrials/Road&Rail) and Grubhub (GRUB) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) – GRUB reportedly rebuffed UBER’s latest offer of 1.9 UBER shares for each GRUB share but talks continue, according to WSJ citing sources. The merger talks have also faced criticism from US Senator Klobuchar who states that any deal is bad for competition and consumers. Elsewhere, Uber (UBER) may cut thousands of jobs in a new round of layoffs.

subject: HSBC warns that today’s risk-on is based on a 'selective approach' to news
content:
• While risk sentiment is clearly supported at the start of the week amid reopening economies (California supposedly 75% open, and AAPL are opening more stores) and news on vaccine and treatments (Gilead’s remdesivir likely to be granted conditional approval in Europe within the coming days, while Moderna’s anti-COVID vaccine had positive interim phase one data), some desks are suggesting a note of caution.
  • HSBC’s FX team state that “once again, the risk mood requires a selective approach to the news. Thus, the market focuses on Fed Chair Powell’s forecast of a recovery, rather than his suggestion that it will take a long time,” and on COVID, the focus is on the escape from lockdown, including the reopening of many Apple stores, but news that over 100 million people in China’s Northeast region are face renewed lockdown as a new and growing cluster of infections causes a backslide in the nation’s return to normal is receiving less attention.
  • While traders are clearly dismissing the news today, it does have the potential to sour risk mood ahead, and is worth keeping on the radar

subject: PRIMER: Fed Chair Powell Testimony (Tue), FOMC Minutes (Wed), Fed Listens (Thu)
analysis_details:
SUMMARY: This week’s testimony by Chair Powell on Tuesday, the meeting minutes from the FOMC’s April confab on Wednesday, and the Fed Listens event to be attended by Powell on Thursday are not likely to reveal much by way of new information, given the proximity of the recent meeting and the subsequent commentary from Fed Chair Powell. Accordingly, the message from these events is likely to be a reiteration that the Fed will take action it deems necessary towards supporting the economy and aiding its bounce back from COVID, although that is not likely to include negative rates at this stage; the Fed is also likely to again call on fiscal authorities to help with the heavy lifting. 

WATCH: You can watch Tuesday’s testimony to the Senate Banking Committee here (on 19th May 2020 at 1500 BST/1000 EDT). Powell will deliver opening remarks at Thursday’s ‘Fed Listens’ event, which will be broadcast via webcast (21st May 2020 at 1930 BST/1430 EDT).

POWELL TESTIMONY (TUE): Fed Chair Powell and Treasury Secretary Mnuchin will deliver their Quarterly CARES Act Report to Congress on Tuesday at 1000 ET/1500 BST, a transparency requirement. Powell has previously said the Fed could further help companies with liquidity issues for a while, but over time, more fiscal help will be needed – a strong hint to fiscal policymakers as they debate the next tranche of stimulus. Powell on the weekend said at least three-to-six more months of government support would be required. The Fed chair seems to be arguing that further support is crucial to any recovery, and that if policymakers are careful about how the economy is reopened, and people take these social distancing measures forward, then the recovery can begin fairly soon, and job losses seen since mid-March may prove to be temporary; he also argued that, assuming there is no second wave of the coronavirus, the economy will begin to recover steadily through the second half of this year. Also on the economy, Powell stressed that medical metrics are far more important than other economic data, which is currently telling us what we already know, but Powell did state that for the economy to fully recover, Americans will have to be fully confident and that may have to await for the arrival of a vaccine. Powell will likely face questions from Republican lawmakers about how much support is feasible before there are concerns about public finances; Powell is likely to reiterate his argument that now is not the time to think about debt and deficit levels, although fiscal authorities will need to step up eventually. Elsewhere, analysts also say that Powell may be quized about whether US banks should continue paying dividends, after some global authorities recently restricted banks from doing so.

NEGATIVE RATES: Fed chair Powell has pushed-back heavily against the idea of negative rates, citing the mixed evidence that exists on its efficacy. However, it is worth noting that a lot of Powell’s language has clearly been structured to leave the option open to the Fed in the future, and other Fed participants (like Kashkari) have also retained this optionality. Such an approach seems sensible, analysts argue; the Fed would be able to exhaust other policy options first before resorting to more aggressive policies. The message, therefore, seems to be that negative rates are not on the radar in the near-term, but the market and policymakers seem to be retaining a non-zero chance of seeing them next year.

FOMC APRIL MEETING RECAP: The Fed’s 30th April rate decision was as expected; the federal funds rate target and the interest on excess reserves were left unchanged at 0.00-0.25% and 0.10% respectively. The Fed reiterated its commitment to keep rates at current low levels until the economy has weathered recent events and is on track to achieve its inflation and labour market goals. One key omission from its statement was references to specific amounts of asset purchases (previously it indicated that it would buy “at least” USD 500bln of Treasuries and at least USD 200bln of MBS); instead, it said it would purchase in amounts needed to support smooth market functioning, which might be taken as a pledge for limitless QE until the central bank is confident that its mandates can be met – in his press conference, Chair Powell said the Fed was waiting to see how economic conditions unfold before committing. Some traders were disappointed by the lack of explicit forward guidance within the statement; Powell reiterated that rates would remain low until the economy has ‘weathered’ the COVID impact, echoing the statement. He provided what has become customary warnings about the impending collapse of economic metrics in Q2, as a result of the virus, but thinks that Q3 might see ‘substantial growth’. The Fed chair also emphasised a willingness to do more if required. And in terms of the outlook, Powell identified medium-term risks: the virus and bringing it under control; the possibility of damage to the productive capacity of the economy; the global dimension, where negative data abroad can weigh on the US; Powell believes that the Fed has the policies to address these, but not perfectly. Another key omission was clues about yield curve control; analysts believe that the Fed will need to eventually implement a Japan/Australia style yield curve control policy that keeps a lid on shorter-dated Treasury yields – this policy would be the strong arm to bolster the central bank’s guidance that rates will be kept low. This policy is expected to be hinted at in the months ahead, likely from June, as the Fed gains more clarity on how the virus will play out. Additionally, desks believe that the Fed will continue to taper its (what has been front-loaded) asset purchases (currently running at an average clip of around USD 50bln/week) to something like USD 60-80bln per month (NOTE: this publication is released before the NY Fed update on Friday afternoon, where it may again lower the pace of purchases). However, don’t expect any updates until the aforementioned clarity can be seen; for what it is worth, Powell emphasised that the Fed would not be removing the punch bowl too quickly, or any time soon. One theme that has been in vogue in recent days is negative rates, after some Federal Funds Futures contracts rose above par, signalling a non-zero probability of negative rates ahead; Powell and Co. have heavily leaned-back against this policy tool next week; analysts are of the view that the tool would only be used if the Fed had exhausted all other options. (see below).

subject: US PRE-MARKET THEMES: Markets start the week risk-on, supported by reopening and hopes of rebound
analysis_details:
SNAPSHOT: US stock futures are around 1.5% higher - with the NQ the relative underperformer - and the VIX is easing (though just above 30.0 at pixel time); the Treasury curve is mixed, with short-end yields flat/lower, though longer-end yields are a touch higher, with slight steepening seen ahead of this week’s new 20-year bond auction; the DXY is flat, and gold continues to find YTD highs; positive risk sentiment is supporting crude. The risk-on start to the week is being attributed to optimism on economies reopening (California is now 75% reopened, its Governor said; tech giant AAPL is also planning to reopen more stores) and hopes of a bounce back (Powell on the weekend said we could see a steady recovery in H2, and that the central bank was not out of ammo). Analysts do now seem to be asking the question of how policymakers will respond if there is a second wave. Stocks in Asia and Europe were higher, although there was caution around Asian semis after US moves aimed at Huawei last week. 

TODAY'S DOCKET: Not much on the data slate for today; President Trump will participate in a round table with restaurant executives and industry leaders at 2pm ET/7pm London, and will also participate in a video conference with governors on the coronavirus at 4pm ET/9pm London. There are some key events on the docket this week, including more Powell testimony and FOMC minutes, China’s NPC and LPR decision; our week ahead briefing published on Friday can be accessed here, and our central bank briefing can be accessed here. NOTE: Canada is shut today for Victoria Day.

FED CHAIR POWELL: There was nothing particularly new for market players in Fed Chair Powell’s Sunday evening remarks. The recent data metrics are clearly being overlooked for now, and Powell stressed that medical metrics were far more important for the US economy; elsewhere, as lawmakers on Capitol Hill debate a new round of stimulus, Powell suggested that at least three-to-six more months of government support would be required. There was a hint of optimism in some of Powell’s remarks: he said “if we are thoughtful and careful about how we reopen the economy so that people take these social distancing measures forward and try to do what we can not to have another outbreak... then the recovery can begin fairly soon,” adding that "assuming there is not a second wave of the coronavirus, I think you will see the economy recover steadily through the second half of this year,” and “for the economy to fully recover people will have to be fully confident and that may have to await the arrival of a vaccine.” The Fed chair also said that the Fed was not out of ammunition (“not by a long shot”) although again pushed-back on negative rates, and he is confident job losses would be temporary. Powell will testify to the Senate Banking Committee on Tuesday, and then speak at a Fed listens event on Thursday. The FOMC’s latest meeting minutes are also on the slate for Wednesday. Powell has spoken a few times in recent weeks, and it is unlikely the Fed chair will have anything new to offer, and as such, his comments are not likely to be a major risk for traders, analysts suggest.

US/CHINA: After the US last week made moves to restrict the supply of US semiconductor chips to Huawei without government approval, there has been little pass through in Asian FX markets at the start of the week, Citi notes, although there has been some volatility in Asian semis. Citi warns that "scope for Chinese retaliation is now a real risk on the horizon, with the country’s 'unreliable entity list' a possible method of targeting US companies," and speculates that China may use laws and rules like Cybersecurity Review Measures and Anti-monopoly Law to investigate and impose restrictions on US firms. "Most US companies included on China's 'unreliable entity list' may be small-sized firms such as US trading agencies, which will be pushed to the brink of collapse; that could serve as a 'first-level' warning to the US over the Huawei ban before adding bigger companies," Citi writes, citing reports in China's Global Times newspaper on Friday.

Q1 EARNINGS SEASON KEY THEMES: Goldman Sachs has four observations from Q1 earnings reports: 1) S&P 500 earnings are partially insulated relative to the economy given its large-cap tilt and high weight in non-cyclical industries. Concentration within the equity market has been growing, and while S&P 500 EPS was -14% in Q1, Russell 2000 EPS was -90%. 2) Online platforms and shifting business models will partially offset the revenue declines in in-person consumption, and restrictions have expedited the shift to e-commerce and other online services. 3) The increased costs associated with maintaining or resuming business activity will continue to pressure profit margins, particularly at bricks and mortar corporates. 4) Several companies noted that revenue declines stabilized in April and there were pockets of improvement in early Q2, but the bank warns that while this nascent improvement is encouraging, it likely partially reflects the direct consumer payments under the CARES Act, which may prove temporary. Ahead: GS says understanding the actual pace of economic activity in 2020 will be critical to sizing the downside risk to S&P 500 EPS estimates. The bank maintains its FY 2020 S&P 500 EPS view of USD 110 (-33% Y/Y) and USD 170 for FY21, but adjusts its quarterly path of earnings growth downwards in Q3 and Q4. Looking beyond 2020, GS says investors will remain focused on how quickly lost earnings can be recouped. More here.

DAMPENING VOL: Last week, VIX started off sub-30, saw a high of 40 amid equity downside, before closing out the week in the low 30s. Morgan Stanley has recently argued that three factors are helping to dampen volatility: 1) health care advances; President Trump’s “Operation Warp Speed” feeds into this, with the programme aiming to speed the development of a vaccine via simultaneous testing of different candidates and beginning production before they’ve cleared clinical trials, with hopes of delivering a fully approved vaccine by the end of 2020. 2) monetary policy, which has been quick to respond to COVID, and has over-delivered, backstopping the downside in equities. 3) fiscal policy; while we have seen 3.5 tranches of aid thus far, lawmakers are split on the next package. MS public policy strategists think lawmakers can come together and deliver one more dose of fiscal stimulus, and then hold-off further measures until the November election. The bank’s base case for ‘CARES Part 2’ is for an extension of USD 700bn-1.1trln, while its bull case is for a USD 1.6-2.4trln. However, others note that there does not appear to be any firm consensus on Capitol Hill, and last week, traders noted that Fed Chair Powell again put the onus on fiscal policymakers to deliver more.

V-SHAPE AND INFLATION: Many have become sceptical about the notion of a V-shaped economic recovery in the US, however, Morgan Stanley’s equity strategists do, noting that uncertainty is always high in recession, but that a V shape is what history tells us to expect. The bank also notes that many investors are talking about inflation again, and although it may be too early to put the inflation trade on in full today, MS strategists believe that rate sensitive stocks, cyclicals, and small caps tend to show the highest correlation to inflation expectations, while bond proxies and defensive names display the lowest. In the short term, MS still thinks the market needs a breather to work-off some overbought conditions, which it says is a necessary step before resuming a secular bull market. “While concentration is evident in the SPX, it is not alone in driving the market higher,” the bank says, arguing that “pullbacks will provide a good entry point, especially as stock specific risk starts to improve.” The key question, therefore, is how inflationary any rebound will be, and MS says two factors suggest inflation could be in the pipeline: COVID recession will be shorter than GFC, and policymakers response has been quicker and more emphatic. More here.

  • President Trump commented that he has lost a little flavour for the China trade deal
